explanation: Carnot efficiency represents the maximum theoretical efficiency of any heat engine operating between two thermal reservoirs. It depends only on the absolute temperatures of the hot and cold reservoirs, establishing an upper limit that no real heat engine can exceed. This efficiency is achieved by the reversible Carnot cycle and is fundamental to understanding the second law of thermodynamics.

equations_assumptions.text: The heat engine operates between two thermal reservoirs at fixed temperatures T_H and T_C.
All processes in the Carnot cycle are reversible (quasi-static and frictionless).

definitions.definition: Absolute temperature of the hot reservoir.
Absolute temperature of the cold reservoir.
Heat absorbed from the hot reservoir per cycle.
Heat rejected to the cold reservoir per cycle.

derivation.equation: Delta S_universe = Delta S_H + Delta S_C + Delta S_engine = 0

derivation_assumptions.text: The second law of thermodynamics applies (entropy of universe cannot decrease).
The reservoirs are large enough that their temperatures remain constant.

derivation_explanation.text: For a reversible process, the total entropy change of the universe is zero.
Calculate entropy changes of the hot and cold reservoirs.
For a reversible cycle, the working substance returns to its initial state.
Set the total entropy change to zero for reversible operation.
Solve for the ratio of heat transfers between reservoirs.
Apply conservation of energy: work equals net heat absorbed.
Define efficiency as the ratio of work output to heat input.
Substitute the temperature ratio to get Carnot efficiency.

code: T_H, T_C, Q_H, Q_C, W = sp.symbols('T_H T_C Q_H Q_C W', positive=True)
# Also substitute W = Q_H - Q_C to complete the derivation
# As T_C approaches T_H, efficiency approaches 0
# Verify that efficiency is always less than 1 for T_C > 0
assert eta_carnot < 1  # for T_C > 0 and T_H > T_C

limitations: Theoretical maximum (real engines have additional losses)

historical_context.importance: Establishes fundamental limit on heat engine efficiency, cornerstone of thermodynamics
